facts.text: Appellant Sarjoo Prasad convicted by P. M. Agra, Magistrate First Class, Allahabad of offence under s.7 read with s.16 of Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954, sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for one year and fine of Rs. 2,000 due to previous conviction.

Conviction and sentence confirmed in appeal by Sessions Judge, Allahabad on March 27, 1958 in Criminal Appeal No. 745 of 1957, and by Allahabad High Court on July 21, 1959 in Criminal Revision No. 503 of 1958.
Appellant employed by Thakur Din, carrying business at 92-C, Mirganj, Allahabad as vendor of edible oils and provisions.
On September 22, 1956, Food Inspector of Allahabad Municipality purchased sample of mustard oil exposed for sale from appellant, found adulterated with linseed oil on analysis.
Thakur Din and appellant prosecuted; Magistrate convicted both, fined Thakur Din Rs. 200, sentenced appellant to one year RI and Rs. 2,000 fine.
Appellant's plea that mustard oil not meant for sale disbelieved by Trial Magistrate, confirmed by Sessions Court and High Court.

Previous conviction: Extract dated April 7, 1956 of judgment in Criminal Case No. 208 of 1956 by P. N. Jauhari, Magistrate, convicting Sarjoo Prasad of adulteration of mustard oil, fined Rs. 80; details match appellant.
No contention in memorandum of appeal to Sessions Court that previous conviction was of different person.
Appellant merely employee of Thakur Din, no profit shown from transaction.

legal_issues.text: Whether a servant/employee of shop owner, who sells adulterated food, is liable under s.7 of the Act, or only the owner/employer is prohibited from selling adulterated food.
Whether the previous conviction relates to the appellant for purpose of enhanced sentence under s.16(1)(ii).

petitioner_arguments.text: By s.7, only owner of shop prohibited from selling adulterated food; servant selling on behalf of employer not liable unless with knowledge that article adulterated, in which case guilty of aiding/abetting.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.7 Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954

petitioner_arguments.text: Person convicted in earlier case different from appellant.

respondent_arguments.text: Mustard oil sold by appellant was adulterated; appellant in charge, exposed for sale and sold it.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.2(xiii), s.7, s.16 Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954

court_reasoning.text: Definition of 'sale' in s.2(xiii) includes exposing for sale, possession for sale; appellant in charge, possessed and sold mustard oil.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Person' includes everyone who sells; s.7 prohibits 'no person shall himself or by any person on his behalf sell adulterated food'; applies to employer and agent alike.

court_reasoning.text: s.16 punishes any person who sells in contravention; no mens rea required; s.19 limits defences, ignorance not defence without warranty.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prohibition in public health interest applies to all sellers; no justification to exempt servants absent express provision.

court_reasoning.text: View of Madras High Court in Re S. Moses erroneous.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature intends to penalise all who sell adulterated food.

court_reasoning.text: Previous conviction details match appellant exactly; no challenge raised earlier.
Sentence reduced considering circumstances: appellant employee, no profit, repetition but special reasons exist.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reduce to 3 months RI, remit fine.

holdings.text: Servant/employee liable under s.7 and s.16 for selling adulterated food without proof of mens rea.
Previous conviction applies to appellant; second offence established, but sentence reducible for special reasons under s.16(1)(ii).

precedents_cited.relevance: Erroneous view that prohibition under s.7 applies only to owner, not servant.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibits sale of adulterated food by any person; punishes contravention; limits defences; minimum sentence for repeat offence reducible for special reasons.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed on merits upholding conviction under s.7 r/w s.16 for selling adulterated mustard oil as second offence; sentence reduced from 1 year RI and Rs.2000 fine to 3 months RI with fine remitted, considering circumstances.
outcome.relief_granted: Sentence reduced to 3 months rigorous imprisonment, fine remitted.

key_quotes.text: 'No person shall himself or by any person on his behalf -----sell------ any adulterated food'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key phrase showing prohibition applies to all persons including agents.

key_quotes.text: Every person, be he an employer or an agent is prohibited from selling adulterated food and infringement of the prohibition is by s. 16 penalised.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on liability of servants.

key_quotes.text: We reduce the sentence to imprisonment to three months and we remit the fine.
key_quotes.speaker: court
